titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: But I cannot see it here as at Quincy. The houses on the other side of the street intercept his rising and setting beams— I attended public worship morning and afternoon at the second Presbyterian church— Mr Knox was in the pulpit; but the morning preacher was Mr Nourse— His text was from Philippians 2.12—“work out your own salvation with fear and trembling 13. For it is God which worketh in you, both to will and to do of his good pleasure.” There is a compromise of doctrine in this text, between free will, and predestination— For as God worketh in us to will as well as to do, we may work out our own salvation by prayer for the will, as well as for action. Mr Knox gave notice that the communion would be administered next Sunday afternoon— Dr Justin Edwards preached in the afternoon, from Mark 2.27.— “The Sabbath was made for man”—and he went over all the topics, and repeated the arguments which he had held forth at the Lord’s day convention last week at Baltimore— There is error in the strictness of construction, which these persons give to the precept— Dr Edwards left out of his text the concluding words in the verse Mark 2.27.—“and not man for the Sabbath.” I quoted the whole last week at Baltimore, believing as I do, that the qualification is as necessary to the religious principle as the injunction itself.— Works of necessity and of charity are not incompatible with the holiness of the day. Dr Edwards gave notice that he should preach to-morrow evening at the Presbyterian church in 9th. Street on the same subject, and should then notice the objections to the consecration of the Sabbath drawn from certain passages of the New Testament— The argument upon which he most emphatically dwelt was the physical necessity of hebdomadal repose to the nature not only of man but of horses.— In support of which he alledged facts not altogether unquestionable to prove that men who labour or travel six days in the week, and rest the 7th. perform more work, and travel farther in a series of weeks, than men who allow themselves no intermission. And he said there was the same testimony with regard to horses— A more unequivocally authenticated fact is attested by the records of the New-York penitentiary that more than four fifths of the inmates of that establishment are persons regardless of the Sabbath— I received this morning a letter from my Son with half a post Note of the Merchants Bank Boston which I forwarded to Mrs Harriet Boyd at Green Bay, Wiskonsin Territory— And I enclosed to George Rundle Philadelphia the certificates of 600 dollars permanent Schuylkill bridge Stock. W Hellen took the Letters to the Post-Office.

Precisely at Noon John W. Jones Speaker of the House of Representatives of the United States, took the Chair and called the House to order— The roll was then called and 175 members answered to their names— 7. new members elected to supply vacancies were swore in— George W. Hopkins moved a message to the Senate to inform them that the house was ready for business, and Cave Johnson moved a joint Committee to inform the President that the two houses were assembled and ready to receive any communication he may be pleased to make to them— The Senate concurred by a corresponding Message— The members of the Committee on the part of the house were Cave Johnson and Joseph R. Ingersoll.— Isaac E. Holmes of Charleston South-Carolina moved the immediate appointment of a Chaplain— The Speaker told him there must first be a joint Resolution for the appointment of two Chaplains of different denominations, one by each house to interchange weekly— He then moved the usual resolution— John Pettit of Indiana moved an amendment, provided that the chaplains should be paid by voluntary contribution of the members without charge upon the people, and said he had prepared a subscription paper, and put down his own name for 5 dollars; and if any one would give more, he would engage to double any such increased subscription, and then he made a stump speech— M’Connell moved the previous question— M’Kay said there was a law authorizing appropriations to pay for chaplains, and Steenrod the appropriation for the present Session was already made— The Speaker said these objections came too late. Pettit’s amendment was rejected by yeas and nays 151 to 20. and Holmes’s Resolution was adopted without call for yeas and nays. I gave notice that I should to morrow move a Resolution, to rescind the 25th. rule which excludes the reception of abolition petitions— Dromgoole said my motion was not in order, but it was entered on the journal— Giddings thought they would trip me up on the point of order, and thought it would be necessary to move an amendment of the rules—but I assured him that rescind was the word.— Mary Louisa this day 16.— Mary E. E. Cutts dined with us.

I was first up this morning at 3. O’Clock; but returned to bed and between sleeping and waking lay unconsciously till a quarter before 7. two hours and a half later than I should have done.— Last evening General Parker, Chief Clerk of the War Department called and spent an hour with me— I shewed him the Note from General Jackson of 25. Jany 1819. declining our invitation of him and his family to dinner, and asked him if he knew in whose hand writing it was. He said it was Coll. Robert Butler’s— The note accepting the invitation to dine on the 4th. of March 1819. is in another hand, not Jackson’s. Parker said he should know it if he could see it— But it is mislaid. I know not whether here or at Quincy— At the meeting of the house this day Cave Johnson from the joint Committee to wait on the President reported that they had performed that service, and the President had informed them that he would make a communication to Congress at 12. O’Clock this day. R. M. Saunders moved the appointment of the standing Committees which was agreed to— In pursuance of the notice I had given yesterday— I moved the following Resolution— [“]Resolved that the 25th standing rule, for conducting business in this house, in the following words—‘No petition, memorial, resolution or other paper, praying the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, or any State or Territory or the Slave trade between the States or Territories in which it now exists shall be received by this house or entertained in any way whatever’—be, and the same is hereby rescinded.”— I called for the yeas and nays— Jacob Thompson of Mississippi moved to lay the Resolution on the Table— I called for the yeas and nays on that motion— As the Clerk was about to begin the call the President’s Message was announced and received— A member called for the reading of the Message. I said I hoped the question upon my resolution would be taken— The Clerk called the roll, and the motion to lay on the table was rejected 81 to 104— The question was then put on the resolution and it was carried 108 to 80.—blessed ever blessed be the name of God!— The President’s Message was immediately afterwards read and some debate followed how to dispose of it— Referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union and 10000 copies of it to be printed— After some miscellaneous business about 3 the house adjourned. General Parker was again here this evening, and I received two pension certificates from the Commissioner of Pensions.

I received from the pension office last evening two certificates; one for Mrs Hannah Allen formerly widow of Zebah Thayer, which I despatched this morning to Dudley Williams at Roxbury—and the other for Mrs. Mary Jennison widow of William Jennison, which I sent this morning to my Son from whom I received her declaration 26 Septr. last— After I had written to Charles to search for Jackson’s Note and G. W. Erving’s Letter of 3. May 1817. I found them on a small file of Letters on my table, and I cut off the paragraph of my Letter to my son asking him to search for them— At the house 4 additional members took their Seats— Several notices were given of asking leave to introduce bills among the rest by Burt of a bill to repeal the duty on cotton bagging and gunny cloth—by James A. Black, a bill to regulate the pay of the Army, and for other purposes—by Phoenix a bill to repeal the duty on rail road iron— By Dana, a bill to abolish the franking privilege and to reduce the rates of postage— I required that these and all such notices should be read— Duncan of Cincinnati offered his bill for holding all the elections of the electoral colleges on one and the same day throughout the Union. The rule required that he should ask and obtain leave to introduce the bill, and that it should be called up with Resolutions— He moved a suspension of the rules, and called for the yeas and nays, of which there were none, 172 ayes— His bill was read twice, and an hour’s debate sprung up what should be done with it— The debate was superfluous there being no opposition to the principle of the bill. At last it was ordered to be referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and to be printed— Holmes of Charleston S.C. then moved to proceed to the choice of a chaplain— At the first voting there were seven or eight candidates nominated among whom a methodist named Daley, from Indiana, who obtained 41 votes, the highest number for any candidate then— I had voted for Doctor Muller, the pastor of the Lutheran English Church in this city; but he had only 16 votes.— At the second vote Mr Daley obtained 64 votes. I voted for Mr Hale a son of Nathan Hale of Boston, who is preaching here at the Unitarian Church—but he was not more successful than Dr. Muller— At the third vote, Mr Daley got 104 votes and was chosen— I was one of the voters for him, to get through a tedious process— The house then adjourned— I received this Evening a Letter from Mr Allan B. Magruder of Charlottesville Virginia, with an explanatory Article in the Baltimore Sun, and his thanks for my impartiaty at the Lord’s day Convention.

I had a morning visit from Robert Owen of Lanark, a man with whom I first became acquainted in London in 1817. A speculative, scheming, mischievous man. He had then succeeded in accumulating a large fortune by forming a community at Lanark in Scotland, consisting of poor labourers but who were said to prosper into competency and affluence and contentment while they made his fortune— But he was ambitious of working his system upon a larger scale, and he came to this country full of the scheme of new modeling human society. He formed an establishment, in the State of Indiana, named New Harmony, and delivered discourses on the new organization of Society; and trumpeted abroad his Utopia till it fell into ruin—his establishment was left a wreck, and he went back to his own country to practice dupery again there. He had however acquired a large landed property, which his Son Robert Dale Owen was left to manage; and he after strolling about the country preaching infidelity and prostitution, till they found themselves threatened with Lynch Law by the rabble, and parted— Fanny Wright now calling herself Madame D’Arusmon and going home to Dundee; and Robert Dale Owen returning to Indiana, a demagogue of the first water, till he has wormed himself into Congress with such fellows as Pettit, and Henley, and John W. Davis, and Andrew Kennedy, and Proffit, the scum and dregs of the political cauldron— Robert Owen and Fanny Wright have now come again to this Country, and he apparently as crafty, crazy as ever— He said he wanted to have a long interview with me, and I promised to receive him any morning from ten to twelve. At the War Department I left Jonathan Amory’s Letter applying for a Cadet warrat for his son Thomas C— I compared the handwriting of General Jackson’s note accepting my invitation to dine on the 4th. of March 1819—with that of a Letter from him to the Secretary of War of 1. Feby 1819. and they appeared to be the same— The House after sundry notices given at half past 12. Adjourned over to next Monday. Lieutenant Ord of the army called on me, and requested my atten to a claim of his brother Pacificus Ord to compensation for services in a public office, against which he says I voted at the last Session of Congress for want of satisfactory evidence in its support— Mr Elliot was here this evening and gave me a list of whigs and democrats who voted for and against rescinding the 25th. rule.

Mr Robert Owen came again this morning, and Mesmerized me for the space of an hour and a half with his lunacies about a new organization of Society under the auspices of the two most powerful Nations on the face of the globe—Great Britain on the Eastern, and the United States on the Western Hemisphere. The materials he says are abundant; and the arrangements are all of simple and easy execution— He has prepared a plan in which all the details are set forth with the minutest accuracy.— It is now in the hands of Mr Pakenham, but he will ask him to return it and will communicate it to me for my examination— It is a plan for universal education, for which the Smithsonian fund may provide the means without interfering at all with my views— After the establishment of the system there will be no War and no such thing as poverty— Universal competency will be the lot of all mankind; and want will be unknown.— All this I had heard twenty-five years ago, and the humbug is too stale.— His last departure from this Country he says was in 1830. when, by his agency, General Jackson and Mr Van Buren, settled all the differences between this Country and Great Britain— Since then he has been negotiating in Mexico, in Austria and Prussia, and has been working five hours a day upon his great plan which he has now brought to maturity— I asked him if he was acquainted with the Fourier plan of a community, he said yes; and personally with the man— He was no more than a Clerk in a Merchant’s Counting house, ingenious and fanciful, without experience of the world or knowledge of mankind— Dr. Mayo was here and told me that he meant to answer Andrew Jackson’s indirect attack upon him, about the Letter to Fulton, in his imploring Letter to Blair the Editor of the Globe— Mayo had not seen my reply to Jackson’s Letter to Armstrong in the North Bridgwater Address— I gave him a copy of the Boston Courier containing it— He said that Jackson was the greatest liar that this Country had ever produced and that the Committee on the Fulton claim had proved it upon him— Daley is a coloured man who brought samples of Gunpowder and black Tea which he brought with him from China. Mr Fischer came with a complaint against M’Nulty the clerk of the house for speculating in his purchases of Stationery— I called at the Patriotic Bank and drew 200 dollars by Check. Visits from J. P. Kennedy and R. C. Winthop Evening with Walter Hellen at the concert of Swiss Campanologians.

I should have done much business this day at the War and Navy Departments and in the Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives, in overhauling the unfinished business of former Sessions of Congress to be replaced upon the Calendar— But Sloth creeps irresistibly upon leisure, and a walk of about half an hour was my only substitute for a visit to the Department and to the house— Mr Kellogg is the President of a College at Galesburg in the State of Illinois, travelling I suppose for the purpose of collecting contributions; but he asked none from me. He alledged no other than curiosity, and said that his college had commenced in 1837 as a school for teachers, preparatory for college, and had about 140 pupils— Since 1841. it had become a college, having now three classes and expecting a fourth next year—ten students to each Class— Mr Patterson, a member of the house from Rochester, New-York called and urged me very earnestly to come out with a severe declaration in the house against the Liberty party-abolitionists— I distrust very much the advice of Mr Patterson— I told him I thought the Liberty party had taken the most effectual means to demolish themselves; and as they had repelled and denounced me, it would have an appearance of private and personal resentment if I should retort upon them— They had done all the mischief in their power— It is irreparable— There may be an occasion upon which I may without impropriety express my opinion of them; but I shall not seek it— Among the Letters that I received yesterday was one from New-York dated 4. Decr., the writer of which says that canvassing a few days since with Governor Poindexter at the Galt house in Louisville he Poindexter said the morning when Jackson had the interview with me concerning the Florida Treaty he had been at Poindexter’s room, and on leaving it said that it was to fufil an engagement to meet me and Mr Monroe on that subject. But it was to meet me, and not Mr Monroe; and this is an anonymous Letter— I had morning visits also from Mr Thomasson and judge Pyrtle, from Louisville, Kentucky. the latter is here in attendance on the Supreme Court.

I attended public worship in the hall of the house of representatives, where Mr Tuston, the chaplain of the Senate began by giving out to be sung Watts’s hundredth Psalm, reading by two lines at a time; setting the tune himself, and requesting his hearers to join him as far as practicable— He then made a short and fervent prayer—read the 12th. chapter of Paul’s epistle to the Romans, and preached from Philippians 3.3. “For we are the circumcision which worship God in the spirit, and rejoice in Christ Jesus, and have no confidence in the flesh.” Mr Tuston in this as in many other of his discourses, very earnestly disclaimed all sectarianism of forms, and all bigoted attachment to peculiar modes of worship— He said there were two points upon which he had no doubt that every person professing the name of Christ of whatever denomination would agree— 1. To worship God in the spirit; and 2. And to place all his hopes of salvation, alone upon the merits of the redeemer— Mr Tuston’s manner is peculiarly tender and affectionate to his hearers, and in this he conciliates their favour rather than by the copiousness the vigour or the ingenuity of his intellect.— The Epistle to the Philippians is a heart searching exhortation to concord—written in prison—plaintive but not desponding—rather boastful of himself and glorying in his sufferings.— It is almost entirely about himself and expresses gratitude to them, as the only church that had contributed to his personal support— I perceive Mr Tuston’s inducement to the selection of his text— After dinner at St John’s church, Mr Pine read the Evening service for the second Sunday in Advent. The second lesson of which was the 12th. chapter of Romans which Mr Tuston had read this morning— Mr Pine preached a short Sermon from Ephesians 1.18. “The eyes of your understanding being enlightened, that ye may know what is the hope of his calling.”— Mr Pyne is a pleasing preacher and a very intelligent and amiable man— As I was returning home from church I was overtaken by Mr Peter Hagner, who came in and passed a quarter of an hour with me. In the evening General Daniel Parker called and brought with him a number of papers from the files of the War Department in the handwriting of his staff officers—he offered to leave them with me, but I declined keeping them— Visits from Mr Phoenix and Mr Moseley.

Sleepless night, caused by breakfasting on coffee yesterday morning, and drinking a cup of tea last evening.— A sluggish, drowy, torpid day succeeds.— At the house, Mr Tuston opened the day with a short studied prayer— On the reading of the Journal the standing Committees were announced. The Speaker has again appointed me chairman of the Committee of Manufactures— Thomasson came and told me that he and another anti-Texas members of the Committee of foreign Affairs at the last Session have been removed and that the Committee now are Texas. The reading of the journal was no sooner finished than Hammett of Mississippi, began to move a resolution for referring to a select Committee so much of the President’s message as relates to Texas— Dromgoole told him that he had a series of Resolutions ready to distribute to the several standing committees the various topics of the message, for which purpose he should move to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. Hammet immediately gave way. Dromgoole made his motion, and the house went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Cave Johnson in the Chair— Dromgoole presented ten Resolutions distributing the Message to as many standing Committees— Only one question was taken upon the whole series of Resolutions, and they were adopted in a lump. Dromgoole then moved that the Committee should rise and report which was done—and the report was adopted without a word of debate. But before passing Dromgoole’s Resolutions the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union had taken up Duncan’s bill for holding the election of the Presidential Electors, on one and the same day throughout the Union— This gave rise to a dull and tedious debate chiefly raised by Elmer chairman of the Committee of elections, of which the Committee soon got tired and laid the bill aside. In the Clerk’s Office, I looked up the bill for the relief of Joseph Holmes, and the owners of the Schooner Industry.— This Evening Mr Samuel Hoare called on me and told me the particulars of his expulsion by mob violence from Charleston South-Carolina, where he had been sent as a Commissioner to protect the personal rights of coloured citizens of Massachusetts imprisoned under a Slave-law of the State. He barely escaped with life and limb— I approved the whole of his conduct, and advised him to see the other members of the delegation from Massachusetts before proceeding home. Mr Markoe called to invite me to a meeting of the Institute, but I declined—

Mr Robert Owen brought me this morning a small bound printed book, by himself, a second edition, London 1841. entitled a Developement of the principles and plans on which to establish Self-supporting home-colonies— He left it, with me, and said he would call for it again to-morrow— From the cursory glance at its contents which is all that I can bestow, I find it a new edition of his old exploded projects— At the house I gave notice of my intention to ask leave to introduce a bill for the relief of Joseph Holmes and the owners of the Schooner Industry. After some other interlocutory motions Giddings asked the Speaker what was the regular business of the day, and he answered the call of the States for Petitions— Giddings then called for the Order of business and the Speaker announced Petitions in order from the State of Maine.— There were none from Maine— One or two from New-Hampshire. The call came at once upon Massachusetts. I had only three petitions to present. 1. from John P. Andrews of Salem for the promotion of universal peace— Referred to the Committee of foreign Affairs. 2. from Edward Jarvis and J. Wingate Thornton Committee of the American Statistical Association, a memorial concerning the errors in the census of 1840— I moved its reference to the Committee of Statistics of the last Session if it still existed, and that it should be printed.— The Speaker said that was a select Committee only for the Session and did not now exist— I then moved the reference to a select Committee of 9 which was adopted—but objection was made to the printing— Preston King called for its being read. The Clerk read about 5 minutes—till they tired and dispensed with the further reading.— a motion was made to lay the motion to print on the table—carried 101. to 79.— 3. Petition from A. B. Kingsland and 4 other residents in the City of New-York for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia— I moved its reference to the Committee on the district. Black of Georgia objected to its reception. Brown of Indiana moved to lay the objection on the table, lost by yeas and nays 90 to 99. Question on the reception of the Petition 107 to 81.— Tibbatts moved to lay the petition on the table—lost 88 to 99 and it was referred to the Committee on the District— Much matter for reflection on these proceedings.— The call for petitions proceeded till they came to Ohio—and when Giddings rose a motion to adjourn was made and carried— John Connell was here this Evening.

Mr Owen came again this morning for his book. I told him I had cursorily looked over as much of it as my time would allow, and that I had not been able to bring my mind to the approbation of his plan— He went over the same preamble that I had heard from him 27 years ago in London; which he had afterwards crowded upon me year after year here, when I was Secretary of State and President, and from which I have hoped for the last fifteen years that this Country was forever delivered.— He said he wanted his book now; but he would send it to me again to be examined and studied at my leisure; for it required profound study to understand it— It was to change the basis of human society; to put every individual of the human race in the proper place to promote his own happiness, and needed only to be put into operation to accomplish its purpose. At the house Douglas of Illinois gave notice that he would at an early day move for leave to introduce a bill to establish a new territory with a strange name— Houston of Alabama moved to suspend the rules to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up the Bill N. 2. reported at the last Session from the Committee on the Territories— Duncan insisted upon the preference to his bill for holding the election of Presidential electors throughout the Union one and the same day. Houston yielded the precedence— The house went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union and first took up Duncan’s bill— Elmer and Hannibal Hamlin still nibbled at the Bill, till Duncan proposed an entire substitute for his bill accommodated to their projected amendments. It was adopted by the Committee, and laid aside to be reported to the house—but Dromgoole was still dissatisfied, and offered another entire substitute of his own, which the Speaker decided came too late, but said it might be offered in the house. Houston’s Bill for reducing and graduating the price of the public lands was then taken up— It proposes to authorise the sale of all the public lands which have been 5 years upon sale for one dollar an all that have been ten years upon sale for 75 cents—all that have been 15 years in the market for 50 cents, and all that have been 20 years on hand for 25 cents an acre— This bill was supported by Houston, by Sample and John W. Davis of Indiana, and opposed by Collamer of Vermont, and by Vinton of Ohio— It will break up the whole system of the sales of the public lands, and will give them away— Mr Hawley was here this evening.

Texas Annexation (1845)

div.p: Much of this morning was consumed in a fruitless search for the pamphlet statement of the proceedings in the United States Courts in the case of the Amistad Negroes There are numerous documents relating to that case to oppose a bill and report from the Committee of foreign Affairs at the last Session of Congress, essentially necessary, but which I have not now at hand— At the house, Douglas of Illinois gave notice of a motion for the purchase of certain copies of Greenhow’s history of Oregon California &c— The name of the new Territory which he proposes to establish is Nebraska— Levy the delegate from Florida, obtained an order to print 5000 copies of the Constitution of Florida reported in 1839.— The call for petitions was resumed.— Giddings presented successively 7. abolition petitions, memorials and resolutions and objection was made to the reception of them all.— Rhett of South Carolina, enquired if the question of reception was debateable—the Speaker answered that it was, whereupon Rhett said he wished to debate it— They were all laid over accordingly one day for debate, except a memorial from Ashtabula County for the abolition of the Slave-representation, which was laid on the table by yeas and nays 135 to 54.— Augustus C. Dodge, delegate from the Territory of Iowa presented a memorial asking admission into the Union and a copy of their Constitution which after some discussion was referred to the Committee on the Territories— The Committees were called for Reports, but the only one presented was by Charles J. Ingersoll Chairman of the Committee of foreign Affairs.— A joint Resolution for the annexation of Texas to the United States, in exactly the same words with a joint Resolution presented two or three days since to the Senate by George M’Duffie of South-Carolina— The Resolution was read twice, referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union and Ingersoll gave notice that he should call it up for consideration, on Monday the 23d. of this month— The annexation is to be a complete ratification of the Treaty signed on the 12th. of April last, and rejected by the Senate— Ingersoll moved also the printing of 5000 copies of the map of Texas which was agreed to— Winthrop who is a member of the Committee of foreign Affairs gave notice that the report of the Committee was not unanimous; that no discussion of it had been allowed in the Committee and that all he could do was to protest against it, as unconstitutional in form and substance, and tending directly to the dissolution of the Union— Mr Frye spent the Evening here—

A budget of Newspapers every morning from various quarters, draw my attention to articles upon all sorts of subjects and wear away my time like the melting of a candle till I am obliged to attend my duty at the house without leaving upon my memory any thing but a blank— I reached the capitol this morning at a quarter past 11— I went into the library room of the Supreme judicial Court and borrowed the 15th. volume of Peters’s Reports containing the case of the Schooner Amistad and her African Negroes— I found M’Kay and Romulus M Saunders in conclave there together.— The librarian there asked me if I was born on the 11th. of July— I said I was.— He said that his reason for asking the question was that it was his own birthday, fifty years later. I went into the Hall where the Supreme Court were in Session, and saw the seven judges in their chairs—Taney, Story, M’Lean, Wayne, Catron, M’Kinley and Daniel, and Richard H. Wilde of Georgia was arguing a cause before them— At the house, the select Committee on the Memorial of the American Statistical Association concerning the errors in the census of 1840 was announced. John Quincy Adams of Massachusetts, Robert Barnwell Rhett of South Carolina, Kenneth Rayner of North-Carolina.— William H. Stiles of Georgia, William B. Maclay of New-York, Francis Brengle of Maryland, Shepherd Cary of Maine, and Caleb B. Smith of Indiana—and Henry A. Foster of New-York. The Speaker laid before the house sundry communications—from the President and the executive Departments and with them a set of condoling resolutions of the corporation of the city of New Orleans, upon the Catastrophe on board the Steamer Princeton— They reminded me of the deputation from Troy to Tiberius to condole with him on the death of his Son, many months after the event; which he answered by condoling with them for the death of Hector— Dr Duncan called up his bill for holding the election of electors of President and Vice President and Vice President on one and the same day throughout the Union— Dromgoole, and Campbell of South Carolina, and Rhett, annoyed him with amendments till he tried but failed to carry the previous question.— Adjourned over to Monday. Doctor Sewall was here this Evening.

I had intended to visit the Offices of the War and Navy Departments this morning upon private business, but a succession of visitors absorbed my time till it was too late.— An old widow woman by the name of Thompson, came with a written recommendation in the name of Mrs Wickliffe wife of the Postmaster General, to charity— Her plea was touching by its simplicity—and urged in language evidently betokening former ease and comfort and actual urgent want— Mrs Royall’s Sally came too for a year’s subscription to her Newspaper now called the Huntress—a tax of charity in another form— I had a morning visit in another form— Morning visit from Mr Giddings of Ohio, with four members of the Pennsylvania delegation, all honest and honorable men.— A person by the name of Harriman came and asked for a copy of my Address at Braintree to which Charles J. Ingersoll has published an answer— He said he had been engaged as an editor and writer for newspapers in sundry places, and he was now connected with the Baltimore Patriot— That he wished to give some account of Ingersoll’s publication, and for that purpose to see my address which gave rise to it— I gave him a copy of each of the three papers containing the addresses of 7. October 30 Octr and 6. November, at Boston, Braintree and North Bridgwater. I wished to have some conversation with him on the whole subject but Mr and Mrs Marks came in, with a Letter of Introduction from Mr Phoenix. They are a young couple recently married, to reside in the city of New-York, visiting here for curiosity, and Mr Phoenix told me yesterday that they had expressed a desire to see me, and that he would give them a line introductory to me, for which I thanked him— Mr Daniel P. King with his two daughters and Mr and Mrs Marsh of Vermont were also visitors but did not come in— I took a walk before dinner— Met Mr John P. Kennedy, and walked with him to his lodgings at Mrs Whitwells on Capitol Hill Saw there, Mr and Mrs Grinnell, Senators Evans and Miller, and General Scott.

About Sunrise this morning, the Globe of last Evening was brought to me containing the address of Aaron V. Brown “to the public at large and to the Constituents of the Hon. John Quincy Adams in particular.” This is the third of the gang of conspirators who opened their batteries on me in the Globe of the 20th. of March last, and whom I exposed in my addresses at Boston—Braintree and North Bridgwater— The Lion and his two Jackals are now out— The first tool of Jackson George W. Erving is yet to be heard from— I must reply at leisure to them all. But the whole tissue of falsehood of Jackson’s Erwin Treaty is abandoned without an attempt to support it— I attended public worship at the Hall of the House of Representatives where Mr Tuston preached from Luke 22.31. [“]And the Lord said, Simon, Simon, behold, Satan hath desired to have you, that he may sift you as wheat; 32. But I have prayed for thee, that thy faith fail not”— Mr Tuston speculated after his own manner upon the extraordinary circumstances under which St. Peter was prayed for by Jesus Christ himself; and started an enquiry whether it was a special personal, and exclusive favour granted to Peter, or a general blessing bestowed upon all believers. That there was some specialty in it was beyond a doubt because he was accosted twice by name—Simon—Simon—but as the whole life of Jesus was one continued dispensation of favours and he went about doing good, there was encouragement for every one to hope that he too in his troubles and trials, his temptations and distresses was though unconsciously guarded and sustained by the prayers of the redeemer of the world.— There is cheering benevolence in the thought, and internal evidence that it sprang from a tender and affectionate heart— Two young men brothers by the name of Tracy, were introduced to me after the service by a member from Connecticut.— After dinner I attended Church at St. John’s, where Mr Pine read the Evening prayer for the 3d. Sunday in Advent and preached from 2. Corinthians 5.17. [“]Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature; old things are passed away: behold all things are become new”— A rational essay upon regeneration with an eloquent and pathetic account of his own experience. St. John’s church took fire this morning just before the morning service began; but was extinguished so that it was not interrupted

This day a grate for burning Lehigh Coal was put up in my writing chamber instead of the open hearth and chimney corner in which for the last six winters I have been in the practice of burning wood— Few persons can imagine how gravely the comfort of my life is affected by this trivial incident of mere personal habitudes— Seven months of the year from the first of October to the last of April, I can write only by the side of a fire— For as long a time, I need the convenience of a morning and evening lamp; from 6 to 8 hours every day.— These are the hours of labour for the day—the hours of solitude and of toil.— I must light my fire and my lamp every morning and my capacity to write depends upon the temperature of the atmosphere operating upon my sense of feeling.— The experiment of the coal fire is now again to be tried; heretofore it has not suited me so well as wood— Mr Giddings, Mr and Mrs Tilden and Mr and Mrs Hamlin paid me a morning visit— At the house, the first business was the question upon the engrossment of Duncan’s Bill, for holding the election of Electors of President and Vice-President of the United States on one and the same day throughout the Union— Duncan demanded the yeas and nays and they were taken 187 ay—and 1. Nay—Woodward of South-Carolina— James A. Black only of the South Carolina delegation voted for the bill— Burt, Campbell, Holmes and Rhett did not vote. The bill was then passed without an opposing vote— Burke of New-Hampshire moved a suspension of the rules for a motion to print 10000 copies of the majority and minority reports on the Rhode-Island Insurrection memorial—yeas 103—nays 87. motion lost. Weller asked leave to introduce a bill to extend the right of suffrage in the city of Washington— Campbell objected, that there was a bill before the house reported by the Committee on the District containing the same provision. Weller moved and carried a suspension of the rules—62 to 124. Weller introduced his bill, and pressed for its immediate passage; but objections were started in his own gang, and the bill was referred to the Committee on the District.— Duncan moved and carried a suspension of the rules to introduce a bill for establishing the territory of Oregon and other purposes, which was referred to the Committee on the Territories. The annual reports of the Secretary of the Treasury on the finances with the estimates, and of the Commissioner of the general Land Office were presented to the house. Phoenix moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up the warehouse bill, but could not get a quorum to vote. Adjourned before 3.

My wife had in the middle of the Night a fit of coughing incessant for nearly an hour, and distressing to herself and to me, more than words can record.— I was up, between two and three and returning then again to bed lost two of my morning hours from the consciousness of existence and the capacity for action.— At the house after notices given by several members of their intention to ask leave to-morrow or on some subsequent day to bring in sundry bills, Mr Vinton moved a suspension of the Rules, to call the States for Resolutions, which was carried; and a budget of crudities of every sort and description issued forth as always happens on resolution days— The first move was by Hannibal Hamlin of Maine was to print ten thousand copies of the majority and minority reports on the Rhode-Island Memorials— Objection being made the Resolution of course went over one day— But Hamlin enquired if he could now cut off debate when the resolution shall come up in order— The Speaker said he could by now moving the previous question, which he did— Winthrop objected to this—and I asked the Speaker to reconsider his decision—observing that the form of the previous question was “shall the main question now be put;[”] and it could not be in order when a positive rule of the house forbade the taking of the question now— The Speaker said no debate was in order now, but that although the form of the previous question was, shall the main question now be put—it might be moved now and postponed to another day, because without the second of a majority, it could not be put at all— Cranston intreated of Hamlin as a personal favour to withdraw his motion for the previous question but he would not. Charles J. Ingersoll moved a resolution that the tariff act of 1842 should be modified so far as respects foreign wines, where it conflicts with Treaties or is otherwise objectionable—also that a nominal duty be imposed on all free articles for the precise ascertainment of them— Black of Georgia moved to strike out nominal and insert revenue which produced shouts of laughter— Ingersoll was advised to change his motion into an enquiry of expediency.— This he was glad to do, and in that form his motion passed— Dromgoole produced a Letter from Mrs Madison offering to Congress the remainder of her husband’s manuscripts not heretofore purchased, and moved a Resolution authorising the library Committee to contract for purchasing and printing them—Adopted— Messrs. Hudson and Asher Tyler were here this Evening—and Connell but I did not see him.

Mr Rothwell one of the members of the Committee of 3. who invited me to deliver a Lecture at the New, unfinished Baptist Church in E. Street near the general Post Office, and to whom I promised to perform that service came this morning and said they had fixed upon next Friday evening from 7 to half past 7, and that he would call upon me with a carriage at that time— I spoke of the necessity of strong light, and said I should be glad to see the place where I am to read. He said it should be open between 2. and 3. this afternoon. I had summoned a Meeting of the Committee of manufactures to meet in their chamber this morning at 11. O’Clock— By a most vexatious incident The Clock in my writing chamber ran down and stop’d just at that time, so that I was belated in reaching the Capitol, by half an hour. I found every member of the Committee present in the chamber when I arrived and apologized to them for my tardiness— I then said I had called them together merely to organize the Committee—to tell them I had nothing to lay before them, and to take their Commands. If any other member of the Committee had any thing to propose, they would now receive his communication— The word manufactures was not in the President’s Message, and there was nothing referred to the Committee by the house— I proposed therefore to record a minute of the meeting and adjourn without day to be called again, if any reference should be made by the house, or any member of the Committee should desire it— Which was forth with unanimously agreed to— I went down to my seat in the house— A page named Cox came and said, a few minutes before the house was called to order, that Mr Sangster wished to speak with me at the door— I went to the door at the side—then to the central door but no one accosted me. I turned back and some one said the man is in the lobby— I went into the lobby—a man came up to me, and said you are wrong, you are wrong, and I will kick you— He then passed his right hand before my face and drew it back to strike me— I seized his two arms with my two hands and held them till the by standers came up and took charge of him. I returned to my Seat— They afterwards arrested the man— A magistrate came and in the Speaker’s room sent for me, took my affidavit of the assault, and committed Sangster to answer for it. Mr Holmes of Charleston and Mr Chilton were present I have no room for the proceedings in the house.

There was no room left on my page of yesterday to notice the proceedings of the house— They consisted of little more than two speeches, both in form against Phoenix’s bill to repeal the duties on rail-road iron, but directly opposite to each other in principle one from Henry D. Foster hot for a protective tariff and one from W. W. Payne of Alabama, red hot against the protective tariff, and foaming for a horizontal duty of 20 per cent— Hammett of Mississippi, saw they were coming to slippery democratic ground, and moved to lay the whole subject on the table, which was carried by yeas and nays 155 to 40— I said I was willing to lay the Bill on the table, if Burt’s bill to repeal the duty on Cotton bagging and gunny cloth should go on the table also— But Houston said no more bargains, and the Speaker said there must be no debate on a motion to lay on the table— Burt’s bill had been twice read and referred to a Committee without a word of opposition or remark. Weller gave notice that he would this day offer a joint Resolution for the annexation of Texas to the United States; and this day he did introduce it— Twice read and he moved its reference to a Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— E. S. Hamlin of Ohio moved its reference to a Committee of one member from each State, with instructions to report upon five questions. The question of commitment to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union was taken by yeas and nays and carried 109 to 60.— Pollock gave notice of his intention to ask leave to introduce a bill or resolution, to submit the question of the annexation of Texas to the People— A Message was received from the President, with the brawling correspondence between Calhoun, Shannon and the Mexican Minster of foreign Affairs Manuel Cresencio Rejon— The Message rails at the Mexican Government with the temper of a common scold, and concludes by saying that although we should be fully justified in declaring War against them, he will not recommend that, but only that we should take Texas and then if Mexico makes war upon us, all the responsibility of it shall rest upon her.— The Message was referred to the Committee of foreign Affairs. The house went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Cave Johnson in the Chair and took up the Bill for graduating the price of the public Lands. Orlando B. Ficklin made a fiery speech for the Bill, and Causin of Maryland a warm one against it— John J. Hardin of Illinois from the Post-Office Committee reported a Bill to reduce postage— Mr Frye and his Son, David Hall and a Doctor Thomas were here; and a young man named Sears.

I read this morning the whole correspondence communicated yesterday with the message of the President, and see the subjugation of this Union to the double slave representation with deplorable certainty of proof— John C. Calhoun and South Carolina are in the ascendant, and an internal convulsion in Mexico happens at this moment as if by interposition of the evil principle to help him to consummate his abominable purpose— The prospect is deathlike— I found the house in Session. Joseph Vance chairman of the Committee of claims was calling for the orders of the day—private business— Hardin wanted to get up the Post-Office Bill— Dromgoole and Charles J. Ingersoll wanted to suspend the rules for notices of Bills, and Aaron V. Brown for Reports of Committees. After two or three votes without a Quorum Dromgoole got the house into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Cave Johnson in the chair— The bill for graduating the price of the public lands was the unfinished business and Robert Smith of Illinois had the floor from yesterday. Dromgoole moved to postpone it and said there were certain modifications of it about which its friends were in treaty with one another— To this postponement Robert Smith consented and Dromgoole moved to take up the Sub-treasury Bill, reported by him from the Committee of Ways and Means at the last Session— It was taken up without opposition, and after two or three Sections of it had been read by the clerk, the further reading of it through was dispensed with and it was read by Sections.— The Clerk had read through the first Section and begun upon the second, when seeing it was going to pass without a sign of life from the opposition I rose and enquired if the first section of the Bill constituting certain vaults in the Treasury building The Treasury of the United States, was the same, as in the old Sub-treasury repealed Law— It was. I moved to strike out the first section of the Bill— The chairman pronounced it not in order, and the question upon it was not suffered to be put.— I gave my reasons however in substance that it annuled the proviso in the Constitution that no money shall be drawn from the Treasury, but in consequence of appropriations made by Law— This started a debate which continued till half-past 4. when the committee rose and the house adjourned— In the Evening I delivered my Lecture on Society and Civilization at the new Baptist Church— Miss Cutts passed the Evening here.

There were about 50 persons present last Evening at the delivery of my lecture at the new Baptist Church in E. Street—among whom were Mr Seaton the Mayor of the City, Mr Bacon the President of the Columbia College, and his wife who after the lecture were introduced to me.— Mrs Bacon said she came from Boston, and she cordially invited me to their house on the College hill— Doctor Sewall with his niece, and Mr Fendall were also present— Walter Hellen went with me— This morning Mr Connell called upon me in high spirits— His bill for the relief of the heirs of Robert Fulton, having again passed the Senate— One of the principal obstacles to the passage of this bill hitherto has been the false denial by Andrew Jackson of his own military order for the employment of a Steamboat of Fulton’s in the public service.— The order under his own hand has been produced but he has not retracted his denial. Mr Connell intreated me not to notice this exemplification of Jackson’s memory when the bill shall be before the house— The business of this day in the house of Dromgoole’s subtreasury bill— He had moved last evening a resolution to report it to the house in 30 minutes after it should next be taken up in Committee of the whole; but the house adjourned without taking the question upon that motion.— This morning he modified it so as to allow 2. hours instead of 30 minutes for debate—this was carried— The house went into Committee of the whole, Cave Johnson in the chair, and the two hours were occupied by Henley of Indiana and others of the democracy, in vilifying the whigs and Henry Clay.— Not a whig was suffered to get the floor, and Cave the chairman gave it in flagrant partiality to Henley in competition with Clingman of North Carolina.A new member from Maine took the floor 5 minutes before the time fixed for reporting, and opened a flood of stench and filth upon the whigs He was interrupted by the report to the house, which the Speaker had no sooner announced than he started up and continued his speech begun in Committee. Mr Barnard objected to this as violating the rule that no allusion shall be made in the house to what has passed in Committee; bu the Speaker sustained the Mainiac. But his own party soon got weary of him— One moved the Committee to rise— Another moved the previous question, and he gave up. I moved again to strike out the first Section— The Speaker said it was not in order. The question of engrossment was carried by yeas and naysto 64. The question on its passageto 69. close party votes— Adjourned at half past 3.

The Speakers in the debate of yesterday, besides those mentioned on the other page, were Washington Hunt of the 34th. New-York District—Orleans and Niagara District resident at Lockport; a present whig.—Bailey the successor of Wise and W. W. Payne of Alabama— Hunt alluded to the democratic nomination at Saginaw for the Legislature of Michigan of Birney the Liberty party candidate for the Presidency—which operated like a spark upon a barrel of gunpowder.— The scene was ludicrous. MrDaily the Chaplain to the House of Representatives, has since last Tuesday made the daily two minutes morning prayer from the Speaker’s chair— This morning I heard him preach from Psalm 72.16. [“]There shall be a handful of corn in the earth upon the top of the mountains: the fruit thereof shall shake like Lebanon: and they of the city shall flourish like grass of the earth 17. His name shall endure forever. His name shall be continued as long as the Sun: and men shall be blessed in him; all nations shall call him blessed. 18 Blessed be the Lord God; the God of Israel, who only doeth wondrous things— 19. And blessed be his glorious name forever. And let the whole earth be filled with his glory. Amen and amen.” The subject of the Sermon was the rapid growth of Christianity; and the delivery was the ne plus ultra of rant and vociferation.— It was upwards, of an hour long—rambling and desultory—interspersed after the methodist manner with little narrative pathetic anecdotes, and with microscopic descriptions of corn on the top of mountains, and the process of nature in the growth of grass.— After the service was over Mr Daily came and shook hands with me at my seat. Dr Sewall and Mrs Catherine Brown were there—and Mr Huntington, the Senator from Connecticut who told me that the Senate would stand firm, and there would be neither, Texas nor Tariff nor Subtreasury, at this Session of Congress.— I called at the United States Hotel.— Saw judge Pyrtle, and left a Card for Mr Thomasson.— Received a note from Mr Samuel L. Gouverneur and visited him at his house— Long conversation with him, and he gave me several extracts of Letters from Andrew Jackson in 1819. 20. and 21.— And a very significant Letter from T. L. L. Brent to President Monroe of 30. April 1818— From Mr Gouverneur’s, I went to St. John’s Church, where Mr Pyne was reading the evening service for the 4th Sunday in Advent— And he preached from Hebrews 2.16. “For verily he took not on him the nature of Angels; but he took on him the seed of Abraham.”— Mary Louisa and I dined after returning from church.

In my conversation yesterday with Mr Gouverneur he told me that while never doubting of the moral obligation resting on him to inform me of the Letters from Andrew Jackson to President Monroe, extracts from which he gave me; he had been somewhat embarrassed as to the properest manner for him to proceed in the case— The partizans of Jackson would certainly assail him as in confederacy with me, and would bring against him the charge of betraying the confidence of private correspondence, and Jackson might deny his own Letters, and charge him with forgery as he had charged me with forging my own diary. He said he had consulted General Scott, and other friends in this emergency, by whose advice he had drawn up a paper which he proposed to publish in the National Intelligencer signed G. which he read to me; upon which he would be glad to have my advice, and after which I might make such use of the extracts from Jackson’s Letters, and other information received from him as I think proper— He told me further that General Scott had assured him there were two Officers of the army now in this city, who were here in February 1819. and then knowing to my consultation with Jackson about the Florida Treaty— But that he was not permitted to divulge their names.

This day at a quarter past 12 I found the house in Session, and the Speaker calling the Committees for Reports.— This was the day upon which Charles J. Ingersoll had given notice that he would call up for consideration in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, the joint Resolution reported by him from the Committee of foreign affairs for the annexation of Texas to the United States, according to the Treaty of 12 April last, rejected by the Senate. But he only moved a resolution to print 10,000 copies of the map of Texas, at a cost not exceeding 12 cents a copy, instead of his former resolution for 5000 copies at not exceeding 7 cents a copy— But Stephen A. Douglas of Illinois introduced another joint Resolution for the re-annexation of Texas to the United States according to the Louisiana Treaty of 1803.— Aaron V. Brown reported from the Committee on the Territories the bill for the establishment of the territory of Oregon— The Resolutions and notices of Bills Resolutions were numberless— Charles J. Ingersoll presented by special request a petition for the abolition of Slavery, and the application of all the proceeds of the Sales of the public Lands to indemnify the owners of the Slaves for their Loss of them as property— He moved reference to a Committee; but the House laid the petition on the table by yeas and nays 117 to 49. After a hard struggle to keep down the call for the yeas and nays, the house adjourned over to Thursday.

William C. Johnson of Utica came in this morning for a short visit on his way to Richmond, Virginia, to see his cousin Mrs Treadway, and her daughter Mrs Crane— I went to the Navy Department with the Letter of Mrs Mary Derby, in behalf of her brother, Horatio Townsend which I wished to recommend to the Secretary of the Navy John Y. Mason But he was gone upon a Christmas frolic to Virginia, and Commodore Charles Morris, acts as Secretary in his absence— I read Mrs Derby’s Letter to Commodore Morris, who doubted whether the favour solicited for Mr Townsend was within the competency of the Department without an application to Congress— But he took Mrs Derby’s Letter which he said he would refer to the 4th. Auditor the Officer upon whom the decision will rest. I then passed into the War Department and had a long Conversation with General Scott, now Commander in chief of the Army.— He commenced it by observing that he had read the Article in the National Intelligencer of this morning signed G.—being that which Mr Gouverneur read to me the day before yesterday.— He said that behind that Article there was a great mass of evidence which he had seen— That there were now in this city, two persons, who were in General Jackson’s apartment in February 1819. when I went there to consult him on the subject of the Florida Treaty— That they had recently each communicated the fact to the other and to him— They perfectly agreed in their recollection; but they had laid him under an injunction of honour not to disclose their names I said that I should probably in the course of next Spring or Summer address my Constituents again upon this subject; and I asked if I might state this fact as he had stated to me, without naming the persons, but vouching him for the fact—he said I might— That it was due to historical truth. And he deemed it the duty of every man to bear testimony to historical truth especially when the character of another was implicated in the fact. Mr Gouverneur had told me that these two persons were Officers in the army. I said to Scott that if Officers of the army, bound by the laws of honour thought they could withhold their names from testimony of facts known to them I would not insist upon their names.— He said—I do not say they are officers of the army.— I asked him to call at my house; and said I would shew him the volume of my Diary for 1819— He said he would— Mr Frye was here this evening and said a young man by the name of Sangster, a nephew of the man now in prison for assaulting me, had been to him and General Towson to obtain his release from prison, by discharging so much of the Justices warrant as required bonds for keeping the Peace— I said I was so far as concerned myself perfectly willing to release him if any security by himself or his friends that he would keep the Peace with me and with all others.

I can give no reason satisfactory to myself for having neglected attending upon the religious public services of this day— Never in my life have I more needed Faith and Hope in the promises of the gospel for relief from anxieties from sources public and private— Never more fervent prayer for direction from above to direct me in the short remnant of the path before me— I have wasted the day with out being aware of my remissness till the day was gone— To the church of which I am a member there are no religious holidays, save the Christian Sabbath; but personally I sympathise with those who solemnize the two anniversaries Christmas and Easter—the birth and the resurrection of Jesus. I had a morning visit from Persico the Sculptor, who has been passing some time at Boston, New-York and Philadelphia— He has been making for a company of subscribers a bust of the late Doctor William Ellery Channing, and has made a model for an equestrian Statue of Washington He said the sublimest event in the life of Washington was the surrender of his Commission at the close of the War of Independence— His Statue was to be commemorative of that act. He had intensely studied for the likeness the bust by Houdon, and his Statue at Richmond— He had copied his uniform, now a relic at the patent Office, and his hat—and his purpose was to exhibit his person exactly as he was in life. He hoped to be employed by Congress to do this work; and he wished me to see his model, for which purpose I promised to meet him to-morrow morning at 11. in the library room of Congress— The day was uncommonly beautiful and mild— Before dinner I took a walk round the Capitol hill—passed on my return homewards, in the Pennsylvania avenue by the ruins of a Confectioner’s shop consumed this morning by fire— Morning visit from Dr Baldwin one of the largest claimants of indemnity from Mexico; with his son, a boy of 11 or 12 years old, who brought a beautiful posy as a present to Mrs. Adams.— Mr Frye was here again this evening with a written statement of what had passed between him and me last Evening about the release of Thomas Sangster from prison; and with a Letter from him to me— Mr Thompson the Magistrate who committed him, admitted him last evening to bail upon a certificate of a physician that he had examined him, and found him of sane mind, and upon laying his nephew under bond of 1000 dollars for his appearance at Court next week, and keeping in the mean time the peace— His Letter to me is respectful and apologetic, expressing great regret at his assault, attributing it to sudden and uncontroulable passion

Mrs Darby, wife of the Geographer William Darby was here this morning with a little Granddaughter— Her object was to obtain my consent to cancel the lease for ten years which her husband took of the house next door to Captain Marbury’s, and of which little more than two years have elapsed— The first years rent was allowed for repairs; the second is only paid; and they have already left the house, on a pretence that Mrs Darby found it unhealthy— I declined canceling the lease; but said I would readily agree to transfer it to any other good tenant.— I went between 11 and 12 to the Congress Library where I met Persico, and in the Senate’s judiciary Committee room saw his model for the equestrian Statue of Washington— He is in uniform with epaulettes breeches and boots, with a military cap in his right hand as if in the attitude of a departing salute, and holding the horse by the bridle with the left hand— The horse is the horse of Marcus Aurelius; and I said to him if he should have the work to do I should advise him to bestow his principal labour on the horse.— He is very enthusiastic in the passion to obtain the undertaking of the work, and says if he does obtain it, with that he will close his career— In the house, a motion was made to reconsider the vote of Monday for the engrossment of the mileage bill, and the discussion was postponed to the 3d. of January— Charles J. Ingersoll wormed in a bill providing that the children of Citizens of the United States born abroad shall be deemed native citizens, referred to the judiciary Committee.— Hammett of Mississippi presented a memorial from a coloured man named William Couch of Fairfield Connecticut now free; claiming a pension for services in the revolutionary War, while he was a slave. It was referred to the Committee on revolutionary pensions.— I introduced the Bill for the relief of Joseph Holmes and the owners and crew of the Schooner Industry, referred to the Committee on Commerce— Houston moved a reconsideration of a resolution adopted on Monday authorising the Clerk of the house to grant leave of absence to an assistant clerk named R. M. Lusk for six weeks on account of ill health, and to appoint a temporary clerk at the same salary during his sickness. Houston had voted for the resolution, unaware of the double Salary—on discovering that, his conscience smote him he moved the reconsideration and started an hour of debate which ended where it began— Belser of Alabama moved to suspend the rules to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, to take up the Texas question— The Speaker called the Territories for Resolutions. Belser renewed his motion. The house refused to go into Committee, and to adjourn over to Monday

Miss Mary E. E. Cutts and her brother Richard D. spent part of last evening here— Christmas day and yesterday were more Summer than winter days, but the change came on in the course of last night in copious rain, first warm, then growing cold and turning finally to a cold snow-storm— William C. Johnson had come here with the intention of going no further South than Richmond—but he received last Evening a Letter, from a young Lady of Albany, a family connection, named Heard, earnestly intreating him to escort her, as far as Charleston South Carolina, on her way to Mobile, where she is going to reside as governess in a private family— He feels himself obliged to go, and took leave of us this evening, and went on board the Steamer for Fredericsburg to pass the night—her hour of departure being 3 in the morning. I found the house again in Session and Hammett of Mississippi had formally put the question to Charles J. Ingersoll when he intended to call up his resolution for the annexation of Texas, and he answered next Monday.— Parmenter chairman of the Committee of Naval Affairs moved to suspend the rules to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up bill N. 214. limiting the number of commissioned and warrant officers in the navy, and regulating the complements of crews on board of vessels of war, and for other purposes. C. J. Ingersoll said he should move to take up a Bill for distributing a sum of money received for indemnities by a recent Convention with Peru— The house went into Committee, Cave Johnson in the chair— Parmenter and Ingersoll, each moved to take up his bill; but the chair said the unfinished business in Committee was the bill for reducing and graduating the price of the public Lands, upon which Robert Smith of Illinois had the floor. He ranted an hour upon the cruel injustice of making the poor settlers in the new States pay a dollar and a quarter an acre for their lands He was followed by John A. M’Clernand another land griping patriot from the same State for another hour.— Caleb B. Smith of Indiana then took the floor but the house were weary of the debate, and the Committee rose without coming to a conclusion. A report from the Secretary of the Treasury was received with the annual report of the superintendent of the Coast survey—and 500 extra copies were ordered to be printed— Sundry private bills from the Senate were twice read and referred to the appropriate Committees— A motion was with difficulty ushered in that when the house should adjourn it should be till Monday—which was carried by yeas and nays, 81. to 68.— I rode home in the Snow-Storm.

The snow continued part of this day, and then cleared off cold— Mr Lewis Johnson called here this morning, and informed me of the present state of the claim of the legal representatives of the late William Otis upon the Government of the United States— He said its prospects were not promising— That the decision was delayed, but that the comptroller’s objections to further allowance were in no degree relaxed— He said he had examined the original claim to see how much of it had been rejected, and found it exceeded 60,000 dollars.— He gave me to read a Letter from Mr Wolf the Attorney of the brothers widow and children at New-Orleans; stating that the judge of probate there declined issuing Letters of Administration upon the brother’s estate, because there were no effects of his within that probate jurisdiction— Mr Johnson supposed it would be necessary that the widow should authorise some person to take out Letters of Administration here for her benefit and that of her children— The question between the children born before and after marriage is yet unsettled— Mr Giddings was also here this morning, and suggested to me the expediency of an address to the people before or about the close of the present Session of Congress, by the members opposed to the annexation of Texas; following up that which was issued at the close of the 27th. Congress.— I told him I thought it would be highly advisable, if the deed should not be perpetrated at the present Session— He thinks there is no danger of the passage of that measure, even in the house of Representatives at this Session— I fear he does not sufficiently weigh the despotism of the party drill.— He says there are forty members of the majority who will vote against every plan of annexation. I dread the effect of the revolution now raging in Mexico.— I agreed with Mr Giddings to speak further with him on this subject.— I had received a Letter from William Ellis of Dedham, with a certificate ofdays service of Peter Dunbar in the revolutionary War; necessary to complete the 6 months required to entitle him to a pension— I intended to take these papers to the Commissioner of pensions this morning, but found I had left the certificate with my list of petitions in my draw at the house— I went and found them there, and brought them home; but it was too late to take them to the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions.

Heard Mr Daily the chaplain of the house of Representatives in their Hall. His text was Isaiah 63.1. [“]Who is this that cometh from Edom, with dyed garments from Bozrah? this that is glorious in his apparel, travelling in the greatness of his strength? I that speak in righteousness, mighty to save. 2. Wherefore art thou red in thine apparel, and thy garments like him that treadeth in the wine-fat? 3. I have trodden the winepress alone, and of the people there was none with me: for I will tread them in mine anger, and trample them in my fury; and their blood shall be sprinkled upon my garments, and I will stain all my raiment. 4. For the day of vengeance is in my heart, and the year of my redeemed is come.” The discourse was an exposition of this passage of Isaiah by analysis— It is in the form of a dialogue, by question and answer. The Title to this chapter in my Bible is Christ sheweth his power to save—and Mr Daily gave it the same interpretation— He said that th signification of Edom was red earth—and that of Bozrah was affliction or distress—and that it undoubtedly meant Jesus Christ— And the irresistible power of Christ in the gospel. The Sermon was upwards of an hour long, for which he apologized by saying he feared he had detained the auditory longer than they were accustomed to be kept as he came from a part of the Country where the preacher was allowed to discourse just as long as he pleased. He was as vociferous and as hyperbolical as he had been last Sunday. As a specimen of his figures of speech he said it was as extravagant and absurd to think of arresting the prevalence of the kingdom of Christ as it would be to cool the bowels of Aetna with a dew-drop, or to extinguish the internal fires of Vesuvius with a Lady’s smelling bottle— As I was walking home I met in the Avenue Robert Owen, who gave me a small pamphlet containing what he calls his manifesto, that is in three papers published in the National Intelligencer and the Globe his plan for revolutionizing the world. And he said he would bring me to-morrow the book which he lent me once before.— In the afternoon at St. John’s Church Mr Pyne alone, read the evening service for the Sunday after Christmas, and preached from Matthew 25.14. [“]For the kingdom of Heaven is as a man travelling into a far Country, who called his own servants, and delivered unto them his goods 15. And unto one he gave five talents to another two; and to another one; to every man according to his several ability; and straightway took his journey.”

Mr Owen came this morning and brought me again the book which he had lent me before— I had wasted a long hour in reading his manifesto which he gave me yesterday, a farrago of confused, indefinite ideas, the only clear and distinct proposition in which is the formation of a community in or near Washington, to revolutionize the world, from a world of wretchedness and bad principles to a world of wealth ad libitum, of Peace of Plenty and of Love, without religion—to begin which considerable funds will be required, and an appropriation of not less than three Millions of dollars— He borrowed in return my Lecture upon Society and civilization, which he said he regretted not having heard, but which being precisely at the opposite pole from his system, he will estimate, if he reads it, much as I do his manifesto.— The Sheriff of the County had notified me to attend this morning between 10 and 12. O’Clock the grand jury of the criminal court at the City-Hall. I went accordingly, at half-past ten— The court was in session, and they were about to swear in the grand jury— Nineteen men were accordingly sworn, and the judge (Dunlop) made them a very brief charge in a tone of voice so low, that I heard scarcely a word that he said— They then retired to their chamber— I was sworn as a witness by the Clerk of the Court William Brent and the grand-jury immediately afterwards sent for me to their room. I went and related the circumstances of Thomas Sangster’s assault upon me; and having stated the facts I said I was aware, that it was not in my power to remit the breach of the peace, but I might without impropriety say, that so far as personally concerned myself I should be glad to see Mr Sangster discharged without further prosecution—that he had not struck me, nor had I suffered the slightest injury from him— I knew not what was the occasion of his movement against me, but I had received a Letter from him, apologizing for it, expressing great regret at what he had done, and assuring me that it was from a sudden impulse of passion under influences which he could not controul— From that moment all resentment had vanished from my mind— The Letter was in the style and language of a Gentleman— I understood he had been an Officer in the army, and had faithfully served his country. I should therefore deeply regret if he should be severely dealt with for his mere attempt upon me.— In the house the morning was consumed in a debate upon a Resolution of C. J. Ingersoll from the Committee of foreign Affairs for having a map of the United States engraved for the use of the members, which was carried— The death of W. S. Fulton Senator from Arkansas was announced and the house adjourned.

The closing day of every year is the special season for retrospection, for thanksgiving, for self-examination; for repentance— It bears every year with increasing gravity upon the conscience and at the stage of life which I have attained, every year with more irresistible demonstration of the decay of body and mind— I am sinking under them—yet I struggle to keep my head above the surface of the flood— My last nights repose was disturbed— I know not from what cause. I rose between 3 and 4 with an aching head; and returned for two more hours of waking dreams.— Mr Daniel R. Tilden a member of the House of Representatives from Ohio, brought me some days since a small album, with a note saying that he had purchased it for his little daughter Sarah, and requesting me to write something in it. These requests thicken upon me greatly to my annoyance; and the time they consume, and the impotence of mind which they disclose is a continual source of self reproach and mortification— A Sonnet for Miss Tilden’s Album occupied the morning— At the house John W. Tibbatts asked leave to introduce a Bill to authorise the People of Texas to form a State Constitution of Government, and for the admission of the State into the Union—and a joint Resolution pledging the protection of the United States to the People of Texas till the question of re-annexation shall be settled. Barnard objected to the introduction of these measures without previous notice, whereupon Tibbatts turned his motion into a notice for to-morrow or some subsequent day.— James E. Belser of Alabama gave notice of his intention to move a joint Resolution for the annexation of Texas to the United States.— George S. Houston of Alabama moved a suspension of the rules for a Resolution to cease debate on the land graduation bill in committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and to report it to the house this afternoon—but the vote on his motion by tellers was 49 to 74 no second.— The Committees were then called for Reports, and many were made for notice hereafter— Haralson, chairman of the military Committee reported in favour of two National foundries— Charles J. Ingersoll chairman of the Committee of foreign Affairs attempted to get entered on the Journal that he had presented a report and bill in favour of Ledyard when he had neither report nor bill prepared. He said indisposition had prevented him. Hannibal Hamlin of Maine moved a reconsideration of yesterdays vote, ordering a 20 inch map of the United States for the use of the members— The vote was reconsidered, and the Resolution laid on the table— Walter Hellen and Mary Louisa went to an Evening party at Commander Wilkes’s. Mrs Smith left us. [symbols].
